paragraph.content: KEVIN GERARD HART MD - 06/01/2012 3:09 PM PDT

item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Get blood tests done at the lab when you are fasting for 12 hours. The lab is on the second floor of the hospital building. The order for the lab test will be in the computer. You may schedule an appointment by calling (510) 248-3996 or online at kp.org or you may just walk in. The lab is open Monday through Friday from 7AM to 7PM and on weekends from 7AM to Noon.
Blood test/24 hour urine test
Try to get more consistent sleep
Clotrimazole to rash on chest
Follow up in 2-3 weeks
Your Kaiser Permanente Care Instructions
Well Visit--Ages 18 to 50: After Your Visit
Your Care Instructions
Physical exams can help you stay healthy. Your doctor has checked your overall health and may have suggested ways to take good care of yourself. He or she also may have recommended tests. At home, you can help prevent illness with healthy eating, regular exercise, and other steps.
Follow-up care is a key part of your treatment and safety. Be sure to make and go to all appointments, and call your doctor if you are having problems. Its also a good idea to know your test results and keep a list of the medicines you take.
How can you care for yourself at home?
Reach and stay at a healthy weight. This will lower your risk for many problems, such as obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and high blood pressure.
Eat 5 servings of fruits and vegetables every day. One serving is defined as:1 medium sized piece of fruit such as an apple, orange or banana. 1/2 cup of fresh, frozen or canned fruit. 1/2 cup of 100% fruit juice. 1 cup of raw leafy greens such as lettuce. 1/2 cup of cooked or raw vegetables or legumes such as beans or lentils
Eat fish regularly - at least 8 ounces per week (one or two 4 ounce servings)
Limit red meat (beef, pork or lamb) to one serving per week or less
Try to follow a Mediterranean style diet. You can find information about this type of diet from books and the Internet.
Get at least 30 minutes of physical activity on most days of the week. Walking is a good choice. You also may want to do other activities, such as running, swimming, cycling, or playing tennis or team sports. Discuss any changes in your exercise program with your doctor.
Do not smoke or allow others to smoke around you. If you need help quitting, talk to your doctor about stop-smoking programs and medicines. These can increase your chances of quitting for good.
Talk to your doctor about whether you have any risk factors for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Having one sex partner (who does not have STDs and does not have sex with anyone else) is a good way to avoid these diseases.
Use birth control if you do not want to have children at this time. Talk with your doctor about the choices available and what might be best for you.
Always wear sunscreen on exposed skin. Make sure the sunscreen blocks ultraviolet rays (both UVA and UVB) and has a sun protection factor (SPF) of at least 15. Use it every day, even when it is cloudy. Some doctors may recommend a higher SPF, such as 30.
See a dentist one or two times a year for checkups and to have your teeth cleaned.
Wear a seat belt in the car.
Drink alcohol in moderation, if at all. That means no more than 2 drinks a day for men and 1 drink a day for women.
Follow your doctor's advice about when to have certain tests. These tests can spot problems early.
For everyone
Cholesterol. Have the fat (cholesterol) in your blood tested after age 20. Your doctor will tell you how often to have this done based on your age, family history, or other things that can increase your risk for heart disease.
Blood pressure. Experts suggest that healthy adults with normal blood pressure (119/79 mm Hg or below) have their blood pressure checked at least every 1 to 2 years. This can be done during a routine doctor visit. If you have slightly higher or high blood pressure, your doctor will suggest more frequent tests.
Vision. Have your eyes checked every year or two or as often as your doctor suggests. Some experts recommend that you have yearly exams for glaucoma and other age-related eye problems starting at age 50.
Diabetes. Ask your doctor whether you should have tests for diabetes.
Colon cancer. Have a test for colon cancer at age 50. You may have one of several tests. If you are younger than 50, you may need a test earlier if you have any risk factors. Risk factors include whether you already had a precancerous polyp removed from your colon or whether your parent, brother, sister, or child has had colon cancer.
For women
Breast exam and mammogram. Talk to your doctor about when you should have a clinical breast exam and a mammogram. Medical experts differ on whether and how often women under 50 should have these tests. Your doctor can help you decide what is right for you.
Pap test and pelvic exam. Begin Pap tests 3 years from the time you first have sexual intercourse, but no later than age 21. A Pap test is the best way to find cervical cancer. The test often is part of a pelvic exam. Ask how often to have this test.
Tests for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Ask whether you should have tests for STDs. You may be at risk if you have sex with more than one person, especially if your partners do not wear condoms.
For men
Tests for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Ask whether you should have tests for STDs. You may be at risk if you have sex with more than one person, especially if you do not wear a condom.
Testicular cancer exam. Ask your doctor whether you should check your testicles regularly.
Prostate exam. Talk to your doctor about whether you should have a blood test (called a PSA test) for prostate cancer. Experts differ on whether and when men should have this test. Some experts suggest it if you are older than 45 and are African-American or have a father or brother who got prostate cancer when he was younger than 65.
When should you call for help?
Watch closely for changes in your health, and be sure to contact your doctor if you have any problems or symptoms that concern you.
Where can you learn more?
Go to http://www.kp.org
Enter P072 in the search box to learn more about "Well Visit--Ages 18 to 50: After Your Visit".
2006-2011 Healthwise, Incorporated. Care instructions adapted under license by Kaiser Permanente. This care instruction is for use with your licensed healthcare professional. If you have questions about a medical condition or this instruction, always ask your healthcare professional. Healthwise disclaims any warranty or liability for your use of this information. For internal use, refer to KPEDUPI#4572.
=====================================================
Electronically signed by KEVIN GERARD HART MD at 06/01/2012 3:09 PM PDT

tr.td: Apply to affected area(s) every morning and evening for 4 weeks or as directed.

item.caption: KEVIN GERARD HART MD - 06/01/2012 2:50 PM PDT
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
Manav Agarwal is a 25 Y male is here to establish primary care. He also has the additional complaint of trouble exercising and low energy over the last year. He is concerned he has a heart problem. Complains of excessively sweating palms and feet. Sees psychiatrist and psycologist and recently increased Lexapro which may have helped some.
Doesn't sleep well. Bed 2 AM wake 9 AM. Lorazepam helped sleep but trying to decrease it. Still occasionally wakes with rapid heartbeat/arrythmia. Wakes frequently through night and doesn't fall back to sleep right away. He is concerned his problems are related to his heart because his father had a heart attack.
He has had weight gain over the last year that he feels is out of proportion to the level of activitiy or food intake.
He has had numerous tests over the last year but there has been no particular diagnosis for his symptoms.
Patient Active Problem List
DEPRESSION, NOS.. (311D)
Priority: 3-MEDIUM (3)
ANXIETY (300.00E)
Priority: 3-MEDIUM (3)
OVERWEIGHT (278.02B)
Priority: 4-LOW (4)
MEDICATONS:
Current outpatient prescriptions:
Escitalopram (LEXAPRO) 20 mg Oral Tab, Take 1 tablet orally daily For refills, please call refill recorder 48 hours in advance.
LORazepam (ATIVAN) 1 mg Oral Tab, Take 1 tablet orally 2 times a day when needed for anxiety
Additional Medications and supplements:
OTC: Vitamin B 100, CoQ10, Fish Oil, Melatonin, claritin prn
ALLERGIES: -- Celexa (Citalopram Hydrobromide)
-- Visual disturbance, Lexapro okay
SOCIAL HISTORY: Social History
Marital Status: Single/Never Marrie Spouse Name:
Years of Education: Number of children: 0
Occupational History
Occupation Employer Comment
product management
Social History Main Topics
Smoking Status: Never Smoker
Alcohol Use: Yes 1.5 oz/week
3 Drinks containing 0.5 oz of alcohol per week
Drug Use: No
Sexual Activity: Not Currently Partners with: Female
Other Topics Concern
Sleep Concern Yes
Special Diet No
Exercise Yes
Comment:2-3 times per week
Review of patient's family history indicates:
Diabetes Father
Heart Disease Father
Heart Disease Grandfather
Hypertension Father
Ulcerative Colitis Father
Stroke None
Colon Cancer None
Prostate Cancer None
Colitis Father
Review of Systems
Constitutional: negative for fever, negative for chills, negative for weight loss and + weight gain
Eyes: negative for blurred vision and negative for double vision
Ears Nose Throat: negative for headaches
Cardiovascular: Negative for chest pain
Respiratory: negative for cough and negative for shortness of breath
Gastrointestinal: negative for heartburn
Genitourinary: negative for dysuria
Musculoskeletal: negative for myalgias and negative for neck pain
Skin: negative for rash
Neurological: negative for dizziness
Psychiatric: positive for depression and nervous / anxious
Endocrine: Negative
Hemat/Lymph: Negative
Allergic/Immune: Negative
Physical Exam
Temp(Src) 97.4 F (36.3 C) (Tympanic) | Ht 5' 6" | Wt 158 lb 3.2 oz (71.759 kg) | BMI 25.53 kg/m2
General appearance - vital signs reviewed and alert, well appearing, and in no distress
Mental status - alert, oriented to person, place, and time, normal mood, behavior, speech, dress, motor activity, and thought processes
Eyes - pupils equal and reactive, extraocular eye movements intact
ENT - Ears bilateral TM's and external ear canals normal
ENT - Nose normal and patent, no erythema, discharge or polyps
ENT - Mouth mucous membranes moist, pharynx normal without lesions
Neck - supple, no significant cervical adenopathy
Lymphatics - no palpable lymphadenopathy
Respiratory - clear to auscultation, no wheezes, rales or rhonchi, symmetric air entry
Cardiovascular - normal rate and regular rhythm, normal S1, S2, no murmurs, rubs, clicks or gallops, peripheral pulses normal, no pedal edema, no clubbing or cyanosis
Abdomen - soft, nontender, nondistended, no masses or organomegaly
Neurological - alert, oriented, normal speech, no abnormal sensation or abnormal reflexes. No focal neurological findings
Musculoskeletal - no joint tenderness, deformity or swelling
Extremities - peripheral pulses normal, no pedal edema, no clubbing or cyanosis
Skin - LESIONS NOTED: striae on left abdomen, fungal dermatitis on mid chest
LABS:
WBC COUNT 7.7 12/06/2011
HGB 17.4 12/06/2011
HEMATOCRIT 50.9 12/06/2011
PLATELET COUNT 283 12/06/2011 , CHOLESTEROL 261 12/06/2011
TRIGLYCERIDE 149 12/06/2011
HDL 54 12/06/2011
LDL CALCULATED 177 12/06/2011, ALT 16 12/06/2011, CREATININE 0.96 02/16/2012, TSH 1.29 12/06/2011,
did not have any studies available for my review
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION, COMPLETE OR PARTIAL (primary encounter diagnosis)
Note: Discussed proper diet, exercise and weight control. Check screening labs.
Try to get more regular sleep. Increase melatonin as needed. Recheck lipids and check Vitamin D. Folllow up in 2-3 weeks.
Plan: LIPID PANEL
VITAMIN D, 25-HYDROXY
FATIGUE
Note: Check 24 hour urine cortisol given striae and fatigue, anxiety, etc...
Plan: ELECTROCARDIOGRAM, ROUTINE, W AT LEAST 12 LEADS, INTERP AND RPT
CORTISOL, FREE, 24H URINE
ELECTROCARDIOGRAM, ROUTINE, W AT LEAST 12 LEADS, INTERP AND RPT
RASH
Plan: CLOTRIMAZOLE 1 % TOP CREA - Apply to affected area(s) every morning and evening for 4 weeks or as directed. - Disp: 30, Refill: 0
HYPERHIDROSIS
Note: Discussed treatments with botox injections, sympathectomy both of which are not viable treatments for him at this time.
Electronically signed by KEVIN GERARD HART MD at 06/01/2012 5:04 PM PDT
